Award.AwardTitle: Sea-surface dynamics diagnosed from satellite data and coupled models
Award.AbstractNarration:
A central question in oceanography and climate dynamics concerns the evolution of surface anomalies of a wide range of properties. Sea surface temperature anomalies regulate the exchange of heat between the upper ocean and the atmosphere, profoundly influencing ocean circulation, weather, the seasonal cycle, low-frequency climate variability, and climate change. In high latitudes, sea surface salinity anomalies have been associated with such variability, and with variability in ecosystems. It is unclear how to interpret the development and propagation of sea surface temperature anomalies, however, which are often analyzed in terms of spatiotemporally-lagged correlations. This ambiguity makes it difficult to constrain the underlying mechanisms, both in observations and in models. The main goal of this project is to diagnose, quantify, and understand the mechanisms controlling the propagation of ocean surface anomalies in temperature and salinity. This study will train one graduate student and its results will be disseminated broadly to scientists and the general public.

This project applies a new framework developed by the investigators to understand how and why surface anomalies propagate and evolve. In particular, this new method to infers sea surface temperature transport fields greatly improves on earlier approaches by decomposing sea surface temperature evolution into advective, diffusive and relaxation components. Preliminary results applying this new method to historical North Atlantic sea surface temperature data and coupled climate model output motivate this study. The researchers intend to continue the sea surface temperature analysis to quantify anomaly dynamics using global observations, especially satellite imagery, as well as numerical models. The new framework also applies to other surface property fields, such as sea surface salinity. Three questions emerge from this work: Why do sea surface temperature anomalies apparently propagate at different speeds to the underlying currents? Why do sea surface temperature and sea surface salinity anomalies behave differently? and What determines the variations in the lateral diffusivity inferred from them? The researchers will use a hierarchy of models, including coupled climate models, to identify the mechanisms controlling anomaly evolution in these fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied how sea-surface temperature (SST) anomalies evolve over time. SST anomalies are patches of warm or cold water in the ocean. They are formed most often by anomalous atmospheric conditions, such as a storm. SST anomalies regulate the exchange of heat between the upper ocean and the atmosphere. Therefore, they influence ocean currents, the weather, the seasonal cycle in the atmosphere, climate variability, and climate change. The main goal of this project was to diagnose, quantify, and understand the mechanisms controlling how SST anomalies move, spread, and decay.

The approach was to develop, test, apply, and disseminate a new method to infer SST mechanisms. The new method, called MicroInverse, greatly improves on earlier approaches. It decomposes the SST changes over time into components due to advection by currents, horizontal mixing by eddies, and dissipation by air/sea interaction. Using the new method and satellite SST observations over the last 35 years, we made maps of the currents, mixing rate (diffusivity), and dissipation rate for SST anomalies over the global ocean. We then compared these currents to other estimates of surface ocean currents to better understand how SST anomalies move around. We also studied the SST diffusivity over the global ocean. The results show that diffusivity increases as the size of the SST anomaly increases. The rate of increase varies from place to place, however. For example, the rate of diffusivity increase with SST anomaly size is relatively high in the Tropics, and relatively low in the extra-tropics. We linked this difference to the different current regimes in the two areas.

In related work, we studied how the MicroInverse analysis method applies to anomalies in sea level and sea-surface salinity. Both these quantities are measured by satellites over the global ocean. The results for sea level anomalies are similar to those for SST, except that sea level anomalies can propagate across the ocean as slowly oscillating waves, as well as by the ocean currents. The mixing rate (diffusivity) for sea level anomalies is also smaller than for SST. For sea-surface salinity, there are not yet enough data to perform the MicroInverse analysis (the statistical errors are too large), but in 5–10 years there should be. 

The Intellectual Merit of the project concerns the scientific value of improved knowledge and understanding of the surface ocean. In addition, the project documented and disseminated a powerful new method to analyze (for example) satellite observations of the ocean. The project produced peer-reviewed scientific papers for physical oceanographers and climate scientists. It also developed new publicly-available software infrastructure to perform the MicroInverse analysis. 

The Broader Impacts of the projects concern the oceanographic and climate science communities. The improved knowledge and understanding of the sea-surface temperature will guide construction of better weather and climate models. Material from the project has been used in a new textbook on ocean circulation co-written by the project leader. A postdoctoral researcher was trained in physical oceanography and ocean modeling. He performed most of the research himself and now has a permanent research job in ocean modeling.
